Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y1J-4441-JDJN-62M1-00000-00Google calls for regulation of artificial intelligence2020-01-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:03ZLexisNexisGoogle calls for regulation of artificial intelligenceKelvin Chan

Google's chief executive called for a balanced approach to regulating artificial intelligence, telling a European audience that the technology brings benefits but also "negative consequences".

Sundar Pichai's comments come as lawmakers and governments seriously consider putting limits on how artificial intelligence is used.

"There is no question in my mind that artificial intelligence needs to be regulated. The question is how best to approach this," Pichai said.

He noted that there's an important role for governments to play and that as the European Union and the US start drawing up their own approaches to regulation, "international alignment" of any eventual rules will be critical. He did not provide specific proposals.

Pichai spoke on the same day he was scheduled to meet the EU's powerful competition regulator, Margrethe Vestager.

Vestager has in previous years hit the Silicon Valley giant with multibillion-dollar fines for allegedly abusing its market dominance to choke off competition. After being reappointed for a second term last autumn with expanded powers over digital technology policies, Vestager has now set her sights on artificial intelligence, and is drawing up rules on its ethical use.

Pichai's comments suggest the company may be hoping to head off a broad-based crackdown by the EU on the technology. Vestager and the EU have been the among the more aggressive regulators of big tech firms, an approach US authorities have picked up with investigations into the dominance of companies like Google, Facebook and Amazon. - Associated Press

The post Google calls for regulation of artificial intelligence appeared first on DFA.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5DNT-5MS1-F021-62M2-00000-00Google can now launch 20 Project Loon balloons a day - Open thread;Have your say on Google's stratospheric internet initiative, as well as Rockstar lawsuit, Gorilla Glass 4 and more2014-11-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:03ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYGoogle can now launch 20 Project Loon balloons a day - Open threadHave your say on Google's stratospheric internet initiative, as well as Rockstar lawsuit, Gorilla Glass 4 and moreStuart Dredge

Google has announced a new milestone for its Project Loon internet initiative, which is aiming to bring connectivity to remote parts of the world by beaming it from balloons floating in the stratosphere.

"3 million kilometers is a long journey. That distance would take you around the earth 75 times, or get you to the moon and back nearly 4 times over," explained a post on the project's Google+ page.

"It also happens to be the distance our Loon balloons have travelled through the stratosphere since the project began last year."

The post adds that Google's balloons now last 10 times longer in the stratosphere than they did in 2013, with many keeping afloat for more than 100 days: "Our current record is 130 days!" And Google also says it now has the capacity to launch 20 of these balloons every day.

Project Loon sits alongside other big-tech initiatives to spread internet access to new parts of the world.

Remember Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg's "we've been working on ways to beam internet to people from the sky" announcement, featuring "drones, satellites and lasers to deliver the internet to everyone" for example?

Also see recent reports that Tesla and SpaceX founder Elon Musk is working on his own "micro-satellites" plan to deliver similar connectivity.

The technology is undeniably impressive, as is the skill and effort going into it from the teams at Google, Facebook and other companies. But what are your views on the political and social implications around their mission?

Should we be talking more about what Google balloons and Facebook drones and lasers mean for society, whether positive or negative? How should these initiatives be regulated (and by who) if at all? The comments section is open for your thoughts.

What else is happening in the technology world? Today's other links:

Google and Rockstar settling patent litigation

Is an end in sight to the patent wars around smartphones? Well, experience suggests not, but one of the more high-profile cases is being settled. Reuters reports that Google has agreed to settle litigation with Rockstar, the consortium that includes Apple, and which sued Google and several Android handset makers in 2013.

Corning debuts Gorilla Glass 4

Corning has been showing off its fourth-generation Gorilla Glass, showing how the screen material used by Samsung and (reportedly) Apple is evolving. The key claim: the company says phones suffering a "face drop" will now remain uncracked 80% of the time.

Artist explores London's CCTV network

James Bridle has been trying to photograph CCTV cameras around London, for a project. He even got arrested - although note, it was a citizen's arrest by a security guard from a hotel: when the police turned up, they let him go.

What does the CIA think of Edward Snowden books?

The intelligence agency has published a review of "Intelligence in Public Literature" by Hayden Peake, including his take on three books about Edward Snowden - including journalist Glenn Greenwald's No Place to Hide. Sample sentence: "Greenwald's often bitter ad hominem rationale for this is unlikely to be the last word on the subject". *startled face*

Opinion app makes podcasting easier

Reckon you could make the next Serial? Opinion is a clever new iPhone app that makes it easier to record and edit podcasts, and then upload them to SoundCloud. It could be useful for independent journalists and sites keen to do more with audio.

All aboard the poo bus!

A flippant title but this is really interesting: a bus launched by Wessex Water in Bristol that's powered entirely by human and food waste: "a 40-seater shuttle capable of travelling up to 186 miles on a full tank of bio-methane gas, which is generated via a process called anaerobic digestion" as Engadget puts it.

Telltale teaser for next Game of Thrones game

Telltale Games has done marvellous things with its games for The Walking Dead. Now it's time to geek out over the trailer for its next project: a six-part episodic series based on Game of Thrones. I for one can't wait for this:

What else? The comments section is open for your links and responses to the stories above.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:600W-X661-JBV1-X009-00000-00Google cautions EU on AI rule-making2020-05-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:03ZLexisNexisGoogle cautions EU on AI rule-makingBrussels, May 28 2020

Google warned on Thursday that the EU's definition of artificial intelligence was too broad and that Brussels must refrain from over-regulating a crucial technology.

The search and advertising giant made its argument in feedback to the European Commission, the EU's powerful regulator that has reached out to big tech as it draws up ways to set new rules for AI.

The EU has not decided yet on how to regulate AI, but is putting most of its focus on what it calls "high risk" sectors, such as healthcare and transport.

It's plans, to be spearheaded by EU commissioners Margrethe Vestager and Thierry Breton, are not expected until the end of the year.

"A clear and widely understood definition of AI will be a critical foundational element for an effective AI regulatory framework," the company said in its 45-page submission.

The EU's own definition of AI was so broad that it "effectively puts all contemporary software potentially in scope," it said.

"A narrower definition is needed to avoid over-regulation," Google said.

Google also urged Brussels to refrain from increasing the tech sector's liability with AI applications as too much legal exposure would stifle innovation.

"Such a dramatic and unprecedented expansion would constrain innovation and disproportionately hinder European SMEs," Google said.

Google and other tech giants are taking the EU's AI strategy very seriously as Europe often sets a standard on how tech is regulated around the world.

On a lobbying trip to Brussels in January, Google CEO Sundar Pichai urged the commission to take a "proportional approach" in new laws for AI.

GOOGLE

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:6011-B8Y1-F03R-N4G9-00000-00Google Cautions EU On AI Rule-making2020-05-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:03ZLexisNexisGoogle Cautions EU On AI Rule-making

May 28, 2020( International Business Times Australia: http://www.ibtimes.com.au/ Delivered by Newstex) Google warned on Thursday that the EU's definition of artificial intelligence was too broad and that Brussels must refrain from over-regulating a crucial technology. The search and advertising giant made its argument in feedback to the European Commission, the EU's powerful regulator that has reached out to big tech as it draws up ways to set new rules for AI.

The EU has not decided yet on how to regulate AI, but is putting most of its focus on what it calls "high risk" sectors, such as healthcare and transport. It's plans, to be spearheaded by EU commissioners Margrethe Vestager and Thierry Breton, are not expected until the end of the year. "A clear and widely understood definition of AI will be a critical foundational element for an effective AI regulatory framework," the company said in its 45-page submission.The EU's own definition of AI was so broad that it "effectively puts all contemporary software potentially in scope," it said. "A narrower definition is needed to avoid over-regulation," Google said. Google also urged Brussels to refrain from increasing the tech sector's liability with AI applications as too much legal exposure would stifle innovation. "Such a dramatic and unprecedented expansion would constrain innovation and disproportionately hinder European SMEs," Google said. Google and other tech giants are taking the EU's AI strategy very seriously as Europe often sets a standard on how tech is regulated around the world. On a lobbying trip to Brussels in January, Google CEO Sundar Pichai urged the commission to take a "proportional approach" in new laws for AI.

urn:contentItem:5T4K-V0S1-DXH2-60X9-00000-00Google Censorship; Report: Dims Plan To Launch Probes Into Trump Admin If They Replace The House; Soaring Poll Numbers2018-08-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:03ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTLynnette Hardaway, Rochelle Richardson, Harmeet Dhillon, Mark PennNEWSDomestic082701cb.229Google Censorship; Report: Dims Plan To Launch Probes Into Trump Admin If They Replace The House; Soaring Poll NumbersLou Dobbs, Guy Benson

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: As usual, we really appreciate it. And I'll keep it here for Lou Dobbs. He's next.

LOU DOBBS: Good evening, everybody. Our top stories, President Trump delivers big on his campaign pledge to tear up NAFTA and create a trade deal that makes sense for America but he did it today, not even a year and a half into his presidency, what took so long? The Trump administration radically transforming the trade relationship between the United States and Mexico, ending NAFTA and creating a bilateral deal aimed at cutting the 71 billion-dollar trade deficit with Mexico.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP: It's an incredible deal. It's an incredible for both parties. Most importantly, it's an incredible deal for the workers and for the citizens of both countries.

(VIDEO CLIP ENDS)

DOBBS: And with us tonight, one of the President's men, working constantly to cut US trade deficits and balance US trade relationships with the world, Peter Navarro with us. And President Trump's approval rating soaring despite the relentless assault from the Dems, the national left wing media, the (rhinos), the deep state, and Mueller witch hunt, of course.

Republican strategist Ed Rollins weighs in on why record numbers of Americans are now embracing the Trump agenda, they're thrilled with the booming Trump economy, but not the deep state and the radical Dems. They obviously don't care whether they tear up working men and women and their families, the middle class, small business, they're openly planning to overthrow the president, to paralyze the Trump presidency. We'll show you what they have in mind.

In California, Republican National Committee woman, Harmeet Dhillon with us on the Dems' determination to abuse their power if they win a congressional majority in the midterms and what Republicans can do about all that. Our top story tonight, President Trump defying the odds, once again, delivering on another campaign promise renegotiating NAFTA for the benefit of the American worker and small business men and women.

The President today announcing, after a long and arduous process, his administration has reached a tentative trade deal with Mexico that creates a more balance and reciprocal trade environment.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: You remember at the beginning, many people thought that this was something that just couldn't happen because of all of the different factions, all of the different sides, and the complexity. And we made it much simpler, much better, much better for both countries.

(VIDEO CLIP ENDS) DOBBS: The preliminary agreement that still needs to be approved by Congress advances the interest of both countries and clearly demonstrates that President Trump and the incoming President of Mexico, Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, are very likely to take the United States-Mexico relationship to a higher and far better place than imaginable before President Trump assumed office.

Joining us tonight, Peter Navarro, Assistant to the President, Director of Trade and Industrial policy, Director of the White House National Trade Council. First, Peter, congratulations to you, to the President, to the entire administration on getting this far with what many people, as the President observed, thought would be impossible.

PETER NAVARRO: It's really an amazing day. I mean I'd go back to the campaign, June 2016, famous Pittsburg speech, the jobs plan speech that President Trump delivered that day, seven big promises and this is a big checkmark on renegotiating and we're not even calling it NAFTA anymore. As the President said, it's going to have a new name. the US-Mexico Fair Trade Agreement, something like that. It's a great...

DOBBS: Wait a minute. You're now calling it one thing but you haven't learned the new thing, Peter.

NAVARRO: Well, it's open for negotiation. We'll nail that down eventually. The point, Lou, I think is that we're going to restore this country and North American as a manufacturing power house, a lot of bells and whistles in this agreement. But what really drives the engine here is the rules of origin up 75 percent and some really tough labor provisions to make sure..

DOBBS: Well, let's talk about that.

NAVARRO: Sure.

DOBBS: Seventy-five percent for the United States and Mexico, what happens if we get the steering wheel and Mexico gets the rest of the car?

NAVARRO: Well, Lou, the rules of origin now are 62.5 percent and they're much less than that when they're imposed. What we're going to do here is make sure we get 75 percent between the two countries and then when we add basically the labor provisions, that could -- that's going to distribute this fairly between the two countries.

And here's the thing, Lou, what we're doing here is we're bringing back our auto parts industry, our auto industry from the rest of the world, which has been stealing it from both Mexico and the United States with some of their own unfair trade practices.

So this is a rebalance that works for both countries, that's the beauty of this deal and Detroit should be very happy tonight as well as the rest of the country. Other industries will benefit. Chemicals, for example, but this is what's going to make it happen.

DOBBS: So what I hear you say, Peter, is you're -- there's still some more work to be done here in terms of negotiating the balanced aspect of this trade relationship $71 billion now, something around 17 billion with Canada, which has not yet joined the triad, if you will, you contemplate that. But how do we get that -- what is there in this that triggers the balance, what triggers the elimination of that tremendous -- as the President has pointed out throughout, that tremendous US trade deficit with Mexico?

NAVARRO: The big thing, Lou, is these rules of origin where we'll bring back basically our supply chain. Our auto plants basically have been turned for manufacturing plants, integrating manufacturing plants...

DOBBS: Right.

NAVARRO: ...into assembly plants. We're going to reverse that trend under the leadership of President Donald J. Trump. That's big. The agricultural provision means we're going to export some more agricultural products. We're going to have more protection. It's got the best intellectual property protection we've seen in a free trade agreement and, you know, when people steal our stuff, our IP, that basically helps drive the deficit as well.

So there's a lot of things in it, but basically, the core of it, Lou, is what you've been talking about for many, many years, which is getting our manufacturing base solid, getting our supply chain solid once again, that's what this deal is going to do.

DOBBS: What do you -- what do you think Congress is going to do with it?

NAVARRO: I think Congress is going to love this deal on both sides of the aisle. The Ambassador Lighthizer should get a huge pat on the back along with Jared Kushner, who worked behind the scenes with Ambassador Lighthizer. He's going to file a notice and get this up to Capitol Hill, which will set a 90-day clock in motion and we're hoping to get a vote on this within 90 days and we think that this will appeal across the aisle. There's great protection in there. For things like biologics, there's a 10-year protection for biologics, Orrin Hatch will love that.

DOBBS: Yes. I'm sorry to -- I have to say we're at the -- at the end of our time. We appreciate it. Congratulations again, another terrific victory for the Trump administration. Thanks so much, Peter.

NAVARRO: Thank you. Thank you.

DOBBS: Peter Navarro. Up next, the anti-Trump hysterics from the Dems, the national left wing media, not enough to fool American people. Sorry, national left wing media, but those are the facts. People are paying attention to what this President is doing and it's a lot and it's historic.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I give myself an A+ and when I finish the trade deals, you watch happens for our farmers, they're going to be very, very happy.

(VIDEO CLIP ENDS)

DOBBS: We take up the President's latest poll numbers. Right after the break, you will find them fascinating. Ed Rollins joins me here next. Much more to come, stay with us.

DOBBS: This is the most attacked President in presidential history. And three new polls show that President Trump's approval rating holding steady throughout the all-out constant assault from the Dems, the left wing national media, the (rhinos), the Mueller witch hunt, and everyone else. According to the NBC Wall Street Journal poll, President Trump has a 44 percent approval rating among registered voters. A Harvard poll has the President 46 percent. Rasmussen also has him at 46 percent. I mean it's -- that's astounding.

Crying clown chuck humor calling to rename the Russell Senate Office Building for the late Senator John McCain hoping perhaps that we'll forget the Dems segregationist history. The building was named after Senator Richard Russell, who opposed bills banning lynching and granting civil rights to all Americans. He was a Democrat. A Democrat.

Another Democrat by the name of Schumer now using Senator McCain's death to try to conceal the history of the Democratic Party, whose last segregationist left office in 2010. Joining us tonight, Ed Rollins, a political strategist without peer, chairman the Great America PAC, Hall of Fame political consultant, he served as White House political director under President Ronald Reagan. Ed, great to have you here.

ED ROLLINS: Thank you.

DOBBS: Let's start with these poll numbers. This president is just -- if you're -- he just continuous to amaze with not only his accomplishments, which are historic, but with his ability to withstand and defend himself against all of these assaults.

ROLLINS: The one -- those three polls, which are really all 46 percent, the Wall Street Journal was...

DOBBS: Within the margin.

ROLLINS: ...within the margin. It was 46 percent last month. So that's the strongest number any modern president has gone into a midterm election in the first term other than Bush after 9/11, which was historic. So he is still very well-positioned. He has 90, 95 percent of Republican base, it's his party. They want him...

DOBBS: They love him.

ROLLINS: Right. It's extraordinary. He's got over 30 Independents this early, which is important, he'll have half of them by the time they vote, which is the key -- the key factor. So I think he is -- he withstood the assault and the reality is that he's going strong.

DOBBS: He's going strong in every aspect of the presidency. He is showing true leadership, true results. I mean there is nowhere that he has -- can you imagine a president, not even in office now a year and a half doing this? I mean it's -- well, it's over a year and a half. It's extraordinary to think that he is doing all of this so quickly and profoundly.

ROLLINS: Well, he -- as a businessman, he knew what to do and he did it. And I think most people doubted that he could do it but he did it. He got a massive tax cut, he's rolled back -- ruled back all the regulatory deficiencies that Obama had put in the last couple years and he's got this economy booming. He's creating jobs. He's doing everything that people want and everybody said they wanted and all that stuff they're attacking him on is all irrelevant to the big picture.

DOBBS: Think what confidence he has instilled in this country in less than two years.

ROLLINS: Right.

DOBBS: Part of that attributed to the campaign which when you look at what he was saying and campaigning on was very positive. Day in and day out no matter how unrelenting the attacks from, what, 16 Republican competitors, he dismissed them and Hillary Clinton. I just -- I don't hear anyone who doesn't say, "What in the world would've happened had we elected her?"

ROLLINS: There are four major deficiencies we had when he came in, one is we had to rebuild our military, which he obviously is doing, and done...

DOBBS: Which he promised.

ROLLINS: He promised. Second thing, foreign policy we reviewed is weak. March from behind or follow from behind, whatever the slogan of the Obama team was...

DOBBS: Whatever.

ROLLINS: Lead from behind which has been kind of a strange position. Clearly, he's proven that he could stand on the world stage. Getting the economy moving forward, creating jobs, lowering unemployment, which he's done dramatically. And I think to a certain extent he's creating -- he's creating a confidence in the country. So, you know, again, the people out there beyond that way or beyond...

DOBBS: Our fellow citizens.

ROLLINS: Our fellow citizens beyond California and New York basically see the accomplishments he made in those...

DOBBS: Less than our fellow citizens. I don't know why just because they're all washed in blue paint.

ROLLINS: As someone who lives in New York now and grew up in California, I could attest to neither of them basically representing middle America or the values of middle America.

DOBBS: There you go. Ed Rollins, thanks for being with us.

ROLLINS: My pleasure. Thank you very much.

DOBBS: Make sure to vote in our poll tonight. The question is, do you believe the biggest opponents of President Trump's push for fair reciprocal trade agreements aren't really world leaders but rather American Dems, the national left wing media here at home, the (rhinos), the Business Roundtable, the Chamber of Commerce, the Koch brothers, and oh yes, Wall Street? Cast your vote on Twitter @loudobbs. Follow me on Twitter @loudobbs. Like me on Facebook, follow me on Instagram @loudobbstonight. All sorts of great things happen when you do.

Up next, President Trump gets another win, another big win, a trade deal with Mexico. But the national left wing media, they are despairing instead of applauding. What is their problem? I take that up in my commentary here tonight. That's next. Stay with us. We'll be right back.

DOBBS: Well, tonight, we once again can read all of the newspapers, the websites, watch television seeing here all sorts of people bash the President of the United States. That's right. Bash him, trash him, insult and disparage him viciously and endlessly. And they attack the President daily, relentlessly. But not because he's failed in any way.

To the contrary, President Trump is succeeding beyond even the imaginings of his most ardent, passionate supporters. Rebuilding our military, establishing American strategic pre-eminence rather than Obama's strategic patience.

Today, keeping his promise to tear up dumb trade deals and particularly NAFTA because NAFTA was a particularly dumb deal even among vast numbers of dumb US trade agreements. President Trump once again stunning his detractors, principally Dems and (rhinos) and, of course, the national left wing media, by keeping another of his campaign promises.

You would think by now they would've learned. Mr. Trump says what he means and means what he says. Already an historic president, inspiring trillions of dollars of growth in our markets, driving economic growth to four percent when his predecessor claimed less than two percent was the new normal and insisted, of course, that our entrepreneurs had built that. The hell you say.

Think of all of this that the President has accomplished. De-regulating our economy, which had been suffocating under the Dems and Obama. Cutting taxes just as he promised and restoring American confidence throughout. Expanding our middle class, wages moving higher. Restoring prosperity for all Americans. Record low unemployment rates for minorities. He campaigned, remember, for minority votes asking what have you got to lose?

Everyone now is winning with this president. The lowest unemployment rates for women in almost two decades. He's rolled back the oppressive values and the policies of the Obama years, Obama the oppressor we might have called him. Who apologized for America on a global scale, who frittered away immense opportunities for all our people.

Do you recall, by the way, a single article in the New York Times or Washington Post or on 60 Minutes criticizing Mr. Obama? Me neither. Imagine what the national left wing media could be doing right now to our great president if he weren't historic and was failing America like his predecessor rather than succeeding.

President Trump is leading America and for that, I'm truly grateful. If you are as well, I'll hope you'll take some time and make your view known in 71 days. Your vote will count just like it did two years ago. Think where we could have been and how happy the national left wing media would've been had we not voted for President Trump. Let's do some more winning.

Tonight's quote of the evening from President Trump who said this, quote, I have a different vision for our workers, it begins with a new fair trade policy that protects our jobs and stands up to countries that cheat. It's been a signature message of my campaign from day one and it will be a signature feature of my presidency from the moment I take the oath of office.

Up next, America's big technology companies trying to silence conservatives while they smear President Trump. We'll tell you what you won't see when you do a Google search for the president when social media stars Diamond and Silk join me here next. Stay with us. We'll be right back with them.

DOBBS: Breaking news now. Tonight, at a White House dinner held for prominent evangelicals, President Trump praising the service of the Senator John McCain.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Also, our hearts and prayers are going to the family of Senator John McCain. There'll be a lot of activity over the next number of days and we very much appreciate everything that Senator McCain has done for our country, so thank you very much.

(VIDEO CLIP ENDS)

DOBBS: On Friday, the late senator becomes only the 31st person in the history of the United States to lie in state at the US Capitol. Vice- president Mike Pence, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis, National Security Advisor John Bolton attending to represent the Trump administration. Google blatantly suppressing conservative media outlets from Americans searching Trump on the site, takes you interesting places, 96 percent of the results from national left-wing media in the first 100 results CNN appears most frequently. 21 times followed by Washington Post and NBC, that is tough going.

Well, joining us tonight social media stars President Trump's most loyal supporters, Diamond and Silk great to see you. And great to have you with us.

I don't -- I take it that you're not surprised that Google is -- well, sort of banning conservatives from their search results with President Trump.

LYNNETTE HARDAWAY, SOCIAL MEDIA PERSONALITIES, DIAMOND AND SILK: No it's not surprising and to us this looked like its tyranny. You have these media outlets along with Google taken and they're suppressing voices of conservatives not only that, but they're thumbing down pages where we can't see President Trump's content or good news about what's going on in our country when it comes to this president.

ROCHELLE RICHARDSON, SILK, SOCIAL MEDIA PERSONALITIES: That's right.

HARDAWAY: And I am not for big government but I really do believe that the government should step in and really check this out. Because this is again it's going to turn into tyranny. We don't need dictatorship, we don't need people controlling what we can and cannot see.

RICHARDSON: And it's also look like a former political lynching instead of using a noose. What they are doing is using algorithms and a form of censorship to choke people platforms out, to keep you from being able to do your search whenever you want to search for our beautiful president.

DOBBS: And people are not paying attention to lots of changes in the algorithms, if you will. Google is now going very shallow in its search results, where once it was robust, it was rich. Now it's directed, it is political in many cases and this is one of them, it's a shame.

And when you talk about big government, the role of government and balancing that against the -- I mean, when you see a biased result like this from one of the most powerful companies, if not the most powerful company in this country. You have to do something and yet we --

HARDAWAY: Right.

DOBBS: We are permitting deep profound economic concentration of wealth. Deep profound concentration of political power.

And by the way, no surprise here that economic and political power resides in the hands of those corporate titans who make up Silicon Valley and the heads of big tech.

HARDAWAY: You're absolutely right.

RICHARDSON: That's right.

HARDAWAY: And this is exactly why somebody's going to have to step in and take a look at this here. Because not only can they control the United States, but control of the world, everything around the world.

RICHARDSON: Yes.

HARDAWAY: These big tech companies don't care about conservative voices, they don't care about they're our president. What they want to do is push their narrative and they want you to bite that narrative. They are trying to control the masses and we cannot let that happen.

DOBBS: And if we didn't have a president like this one, I don't know where would be -- he has his own access to he -- to the American people. Over a hundred million Americans are in social media, without that, can you imagine as is all of those folks are with the Washington Post and The New York Times are clucking about the president using Twitter, they don't like that so much.

HARDAWAY: Well, they may not like it Lou, but here's the thing, he have to use Twitter to get his message out.

DOBBS: Absolutely.

HARDAWAY: Because the left-wing media is going to beat him up.

RICHARDSON: That's right.

HARDAWAY: They're going to run their narrative, they're going to play games and they're going to use smear tactics to smear him. So he had to get his message out through social media.

DOBBS: And that it's working for him and as I say, I don't think -- thank goodness he had that Twitter account.

I want to just show you something, a reporter to -- yesterday trying to create a little controversy and a story, asking Tiger Woods about race relations. Trying to figure out how he could get Tiger Woods involved in politics and sports. Here's what happened.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIGER WOODS, AMERICAN PROFESSIONAL GOLFER: He's the president of the United States, you have to respect the office. And the matter of who was in the office, you may like, dislike the personality or the politics. But we all must respect office.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: I have to give Tiger Woods all the credit in the world. Because he stood up, he could have deflected, he could have just simply ignored the question about the relationship of the President and he said it straight up. I have to tell you, it's nice to see that Prescott Tiger Woods and others stand up for this president and the office he holds, your thoughts.

HARDAWAY: It is nice to see.

RICHARDSON: Yes.

HARDAWAY: You know, Tiger Woods he played golf, the president's friend and letting people know -- listen, you have to respect the office. You have to respect the Oval Office.

If you look at what's happening in our country, what's been happening almost two years now, there's been blatant disrespect for this sitting president. I imagine if this was Barack Hussein Obama, all chains and fences were broke loose in this country. So, to have someone like Tiger Woods stand up and say, whatever you may think you still have to respect the highest office.

RICHARDSON: That's right.

HARDAWAY: Kudos to Tiger Woods he was telling the truth about that.

RICHARDSON: That's right, he certainly was.

DOBBS: And it wouldn't have hurt for that reporter to show a little respect for probably not only one of the greatest -- not probably, greatest golfers in history but also one of the smartest. He did a terrific job, as well as a principled response.

Diamond and Silk, always great to see you. Thanks for being with us.

RICHARDSON: Thank you for having us.

HARDAWAY: Thank you for having us.

DOBBS: And I get to do a little promo now. Be sure to check out Diamond and Silk's Chit Chat Tour. Next stop, October 7th Marietta Georgia. You guys have fun, thanks for being with us.

Up next, the radical Dimms out for blood, planning to stall the president's policies and agenda if they went back control of the House.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. ERIC SWALWELL (D), CALIFORNIA: The best thing we can do is promise the American people, if we are given the majority that we will conduct the investigations the Republicans are unwilling to conduct. Including this campaign finance violation, including the questions around his contacts with the Russians and including his tax returns.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Well, we'll take up how Republicans can fight back. Next, Harmeet Dhillon joins us, stay with us.

DOBBS: Congressional Republicans are reportedly preparing for a barrage of legal investigations and illegal investigations, I assume. Should the radical Dimms take back control of the House and they have some good reason, apparently. Just listen to the anti-Trump rhetoric they've been drivelling.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I rise today Mr. speaker to call for the impeachment of the President of the United States of America.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: President Trump's decision to end DACA is a despicable act of political cowardice.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This executive order was mean-spirited and on America.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The president's fitness for office is something that is being called into question. I'm very worried about his fitness.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I know some of the Democrats are saying, please don't mention the word impeachment. Don't worry about the investigation, let Mueller take care of that. We have got to talk about our issues. We can do both.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: They do somehow regain the House. The Dimms will be left without their greatest asset and obstruction that of course would be -- well, lame- duck Speaker Paul Ryan. He's going away, we are assured.

Joining us tonight Harmeet Dhillon, attorney RNC committee woman for the great state of California. Harmeet, great to have you with us.

Let's start --

HARMEET DHILLON, REPUBLICAN NATIONAL COMMITTEE WOMAN, CALIFORNIA: Thanks Lou.

DOBBS: -- this spreadsheet. Whose office do you suppose leaked that?

DHILLON: Well, I mean, I have my suspicions but it's not crazy for the Republicans to be preparing for what happens in case they fail to motivate the voters and hold on to Congress because it is a hundred percent that Democrats are going to do this.

DOBBS: Now, wait a minute -- wait a minute. Harmeet, I got to ask you about that. Because they were preparing for how many years to end Obamacare to wipe it out. Careful planning there by the Republicans. I've not seen a correlation between House Republicans and their careful preparation and result at all in anything.

DHILLON: I can't disagree with you Lou. I mean, the reality is that they did fail to do a lot of the things that they promised. Obamacare is front and center but they've been obstructing some of the president's agenda on a number of fronts. And now they're looking out for their own hides and I mean that is actually what the Democrats are looking for.

The president is somebody who seems to be impervious to their threats and their bullying but all these other people are not. And so the Democrats are counting on taking control of the House and then using all of these different committees. Not just one committee, not just impeachment but harassment at every level of members of the administration and making it unattractive for Republicans to want to serve in the administration or in Congress. And you know, that's a significant risk if we don't perform well in the midterms.

DOBBS: You know, as you and I have discussed, as the chair of the RNC Ronna McDaniel's has pointed out, every Republicans should be attaching themselves to the Trump agenda. We're told as many as 40 percent are not doing that. That's why a lot of savants are very worried about keeping control of the House because the Chamber of Commerce, Paul Ryan is doing nothing apparently. I'm told reliably, he's not raising money, he can't raise money because he's a lame duck and not particularly beloved by his party. He's not campaigning for anybody.

What in the -- why in the world is the Republican Party and the Republican Conference in the House putting up with this Ryan fellow?

DHILLON: Well, I think that was a tactical error frankly, but I will say to be fair to the Republicans that other leadership besides Paul Ryan is out there on the campaign trail. Kevin McCarthy's out there raising money and I think that a lot of them are very concerned about this for good reason.

DOBBS: You know, they'd be out there anyway.

DHILLON: Well, yes. I mean, I -- some of them are doing their jobs but it would have been better to replace him, I totally agree. And the concern is not so much about advancing the president's agenda and conservative values but about their own seats and their own -- you know, political futures and lobbying careers for some of them. So I mean that is certainly a concern.

DOBBS: Does it -- does it occur to anyone in the Republican Party this president may just get sick of all this nonsense? He gets no support from the leaders in Capitol Hill, he is attacked by RINOs in his own party, he's attacked by the establishment where this Democratic, Republican and you've got so few people actually standing up shoulder-to-shoulder with this president.

I mean honestly, it takes a big man not to just say the hell with it because people are sitting here, they're looking around they see the economy growing at four-plus percent. They see the markets trillions of dollars added to it, jobs like never before and he has to put up with nonsense like he's a racist.

He's done more for the minorities in this country than I any president and in frankly decades. It's just ignorance. And the National left-wing media there are unscrupulous to the point of outright corruption.

DHILLON: Yes, absolutely. I mean, you have members of Congress who are calling for the physical harassment of members of this administration. You have the media constantly badgering and demagoguery there. And so it becomes miserable for normal people with lives and wives and husbands and children to go through that every day and the Democrats are counting on that. So you know, it is going to be tough times for some of these people if the Democrats are going to hold hearings and this nonsense every day.

DOBBS: You know, I can -- I got to be honest with you, Harmeet. I mean, I'm talking about the President. He's got everything -- I mean he's achieved more in his lifetime. He doesn't need this. He's already historic. I mean, if he stopped right now, he goes down in the history books for what he's done. I mean, people don't think about this rationally. He's done more a year and a half than Obama did in eight years. And by the way, what little he did, this president has already rolled back.

DHILLON: Right and I think the American people are seeing that Lou, but it is incumbent on us Republicans to make sure they turn out and vote because the stakes are high regardless of the fact that the president has this much success, if the Democrats are able to stall his agenda going forward further than we're looking two years of gridlock and that we were very bad for the country because there's a lot more that the President needs to accomplish once he has a fresh set of members of Congress there hopefully to support him.

And so you know, I really hope that we are able to motivate people and get out there because we don't need more (INAUDIBLE) and more gridlock in Congress.

DOBBS: Well, every time you hear -- you know, every time I hear one more RINO spewing blather on Capitol Hill, I can't imagine why anybody would vote for said and spewer of said blather. I mean, I want every -- this president to have an absolute firewall between himself and these fools who are attacking him but honestly, I mean, the American people have got to be getting sick of these fools who call themselves Congressmen and Republicans simultaneously and you know that they don't do much of a job at either.

DHILLON: Look, I can't disagree with you, Lou. We need better from Congress. You know, we have some disappointing members on our side, a lot of disappointing members on the other side and time for some of these people to go. Some of them will get voted out. But you know, it's up to - - it's up to all of us to hold the line like you said a firewall. We really need this President to complete his agenda in the next two years and that means these people have to do their jobs as well.

DOBBS: Well, if we're going to do that, let's just consider it six years shall we?

DHILLON: Absolutely. I hope you like you said, I hope he doesn't get sick of all this drama.

DOBBS: Yes, and there's a good way to take care of that come November. What have we got, 71 days I said earlier, collective bargaining.

DHILLON: Yes, that's right.

DOBBS: Harmeet, thank you very much. Harmeet Dhillon, it's always great to talk with you. Thanks for being with us. Collective bargaining has made its way to our prison system. Inmates across the country striking for better food, fair pay, and work, and an end to what they call modern slavery. Among those protesting are at least 60 illegal immigrants in Tacoma, Washington. We'll tell you all about that next. President Trump's poll numbers soaring despite the efforts of the radical Dems and the National left-wing media. We take it up with former pollster Mark Penn, that's right a Democrat, a Clintonite once upon a time, after the break we'll be right back. Stay with us.

LOU: On Wall Street, Stocks closing higher. The Dow gaining 260 points almost, closing about 26,000, the S&P up 22 at an all-time high, the Nasdaq and 72 points, about 8,000 for the first time in history, that's an all- time high by the way, volume on the big board 2.8 billion shares. A reminder to listen to my reports three times a day coast-to-coast on the Salem Radio Network. Joining us tonight, Mark Penn, Pollster, former Hillary Clinton Advisor, great American. Good to have you with us, Mark.

MARK PENN, POLLSTER: Thank you. Good evening.

DOBBS: I want to if I may start with these poll numbers. I'm just interested in what you -- how you react to President Trump holding at 44, 46 in two polls despite the pummeling he takes every day.

PENN: Well, I'm a co-director of the Harvard CAPS Harris Poll and (INAUDIBLE) and I was surprised as anybody else that he held about 46 percent job approval after the pummeling I think that he clearly got in the media. But remember, I polled for President Clinton during very similar situation when the economy was good, he got hit with Monica Lewinski and we kept our ratings above 50 to see the same thing that public saying you know what, this is not about issues that affect me.

DOBBS: And yet, there is not even so much as a blanch. They don't even blush these Dems as they go off on all sorts of salacious nonsense that is irrelevant as you say to nearly all Americans. It is pure titillation at best and has nothing to do with conspiracy collusion with Russians, all of the nonsense that has been you know, spewed by actually a Republican Justice Department. It's extraordinary.

PENN: Well, as you know, I spent a year fighting Ken Starr because I thought this was the wrong direction, a wasted year for the country then. And I think it is a wasted year here in term of so much airtime with Mueller and now the Cohen investigation. Look, I was really stunned when it was quite clear that they got Cohen to plead guilty to things that were not even crimes in order to try to reach out to implicate President Trump- related to this campaign contributions, which frankly should and a civil fine matter even if they were campaign contributions, which I highly doubt they are based on my -- based on my long experience with campaigns.

DOBBS: And your judgment that Hillary Clinton gives every appearance of being far guiltier than anyone associated with a special counsel, at least the targets of this special counsel to this point. She was given a free pass. What should -- give the President some counsel here tonight.

PENN: Well look, the President has got to defeat the Mueller investigation and I think he's doing basically the right thing. I think his people have to be -- and his tweets often times go over the top. But I think when you go back, is this investigation bias? Yes, it is. Was the foundation corrupt? Well, it really was. The more you look at what happened at the FBI. Has this now kind of somehow transmuted back towards 1998 all over again where we are looking at the private lives you know, of our President and trying to create fines there, yes, it has.

And I think any fair person now sees that, which is why we've got to remove these kinds of investigations from politics and let elections decide things.

DOBBS: In The Hill, you had written a piece talking about Fusion GPS and writing, there is no question that hiring spies to do opposition research in Russia would qualify as a campaign expenditure and yet no prosecution and it's bearing everyone associated in the Justice Department. The FBI, they're looking at it and the Dems looking at it, and yet they don't want to take that on for some strange and I'm sure corrupt reason.

PENN: Well, what I was trying to contrast was they had stretched everything imaginable to try to implicate Trump-related to these nondisclosure payments related to things from a decade ago. At the same time, clearly, the expenditures that were made to Fusion GPS and Christopher Steele by current election law really had to be reported for what they were and not used as a law firm for a cut out for that.

That's clear. I'm not suggesting, by the way, that Hillary and her campaign should have been prosecuted. I'm suggesting that equal treatment should have occurred here and both of these things should have been called out and adjudicated, in the Edwards case, it's already been adjudicated that these nondisclosure payments are campaign contributions but personal and on the other hand, this probably was (INAUDIBLE) was a campaign expenditure, not properly to screw. People don't do to jail for this. They get fined. It gets brought out to the public. This is way over the top.

DOBBS: I bet next you're going to tell me that there is -- attorney-client privileges should be respected by the FBI except when it implies of course to President Trump.

PENN: Well, you've never seen the kind of deference that was accorded to attorneys working with Hillary versus the complete opposite. Look, any school child could see that this is a stacked deck here out to get the President and that's why this is wrong.

DOBBS: Mark Penn, it's good to have you with us. I hope you come back soon.

PENN: Thank you. Thank you.

DOBBS: Well, this is where we are and what we're looking at tomorrow. President Trump announcing he's renegotiating NAFTA. He's reached a new trade deal with Mexico, Canada yet to be brought in. Director of the White House National Trade Council Peter Navarro joined us to tell how this will restore strength in the auto industry for example.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PETER NAVARRO, DIRECTOR, WHITE HOUSE NATIONAL TRADE COUNCIL: What we are doing here is bringing back our auto parts industry, our auto industry for the rest of the world which has been stealing it from both Mexico and the United States with some of their own unfair trade practices. So this is a rebalance for both countries. \

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Also tonight, President's Trump's approval ratings holding steady despite constant attacks, vicious attacks from the national left-wing media, the Dems. Republican Strategist Ed Rollins saying the President approaches the mid-term elections with some of the strongest poll numbers of any modern President. Look out, fireworks ahead. And 96 percent of Google searches for Trump in the end results for the left wing media. Diamond and Silk say this is nothing more than censorship by the giant tech companies.

And that's if for us tonight. Please join us tomorrow. We'll be talking with Sidney Powell and Congressman Jim Jordan about what lies ahead for Republicans in the House. Will, they keep the majority and will Jim Jordan take over the speakership, among the questions. Please be with us tomorrow, thanks for being with us tonight. Good night from New York.

GUY BENSON, FOX NEWS RADIO HOST: Thank you for the privilege of serving you. That from the late Senator John McCain in a moving farewell letter to the nation he loved.
